"""Monitoring and Evaluation Framework with Tools
Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) Project
Date: November 25, 2024

1. Introduction
1.1 Background
The BEIT project aims to stimulate decent work opportunities for young women and men while addressing the urgent need for affordable housing in Iraq. Under Output 3.3, the project focuses on strengthening the capacities of local businesses, particularly young entrepreneurs, for integrating green and innovative practices in their operations. This includes providing financial literacy training to enhance their knowledge and skills.
1.2 Purpose of the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework
The goal is to align continual curriculum improvements, as described in the Material Validation report, with the required M&E results needed for the BEIT project. Based on our experience working in Mosul, we have identified the need to leverage simple, paper-based, tools to gather the required data. It includes:
Assessment Tools: Pre- and post-assessment quizzes to measure knowledge acquisition for the Financial Literacy Module. 
Feedback Forms: Participant feedback forms to gather qualitative data on training effectiveness, names, 
Competency Criteria: Specific criteria for measuring competency acquisition among participants.
Data Collection and Analysis Methodologies: Procedures for collecting, analyzing, and reporting data to inform future training improvements and assess the program's impact.

2. M&E Framework Overview

2.1 Objectives
Assess Learning Outcomes: Measure the increase in participants' knowledge and skills as a result of the training.
Evaluate Training Effectiveness: Gather feedback on training delivery, content relevance, and participant satisfaction.
Inform Program Improvements: Use data to refine training materials and methodologies.
Report on Impact: Provide evidence of the training program's impact on professionals in the construction and housing sector.
2.2 Alignment with BEIT Logframe Indicators
The M&E framework aligns with the following BEIT Output 3.3 indicators:

Indicator 3.3.1: Number of firms benefiting from green Business Development Services (BDS).
Indicator 3.3.2: Number of people who have benefited from institution or workplace-based TVET/skills development interventions.
Indicator 3.3.3: Number of people benefiting from financial literacy training who can demonstrate increased knowledge.
Indicator 3.3.4: Number of key support organizations having improved operational or managerial performance as a result of ITC support.
3. Integration of the ADDIE Model into the M&E Framework
The ADDIE model consists of five phases: Analyze, Design, Develop, Implement, and Evaluate. Each phase includes specific activities and corresponding monitoring and evaluation components.

Analyze - Identify learning needs and objectives.
Needs Assessment Surveys and Focus Groups: Collect data on learners' existing knowledge and skills. Analysis can be found in the Stakeholder Engagement Recommendations and Material Validation report. 
Design - Develop learning objectives and outcomes
Develop - Take feedback from the implementation phase and update the curriculum.
Relevant Tools:
Post Module Feedback Forms: Gather insights from participants to inform curriculum improvements.
Training Feedback Forms: Gather real-time feedback during training sessions.
Observation Reports: Trainers assess engagement and participation levels, and report insights and concerns to the implementing partner.
Evaluate
Activities to be done by implementing partner after each module is operated.
Review feedback forms and assess the effectiveness of the training program.
Gather insights from lead trainer.
Identify areas for improvement.
Update M&E tools and generate reports.
Return to the analysis phase and continue the ADDIE cycle
M&E Components:
Pre- and Post-Training Assessments: Measure learning outcomes for financial literacy. The assessment can be found in Appendix A. 
Post-Module Quiz: Measures learning and qualifies learners for completing the module successfully (70% or more).
Post-Module Assessments: Evaluate each module's impact, web-fillable forms as well as printable PDFs are available in this folder. 
4. Tools and Instruments of the M&E Framework

Monitoring and Evaluation is an important element of a program, our goal in the M&E approach is to align M&E needs with the ADDIE continual improvement framework for the curriculum. This streamlines the data acquisition process and leverages needed information for developing a stronger training program. 

The three main components we will use are pre-post test assessments for the Financial Literacy module, a post-module evaluation form, and a post-module quiz.
4.1 Financial Literacy Pre/Post-Test Questionnaire
A standardized test to be delivered before and after the Financial Literacy Module comprising multiple-choice and short-answer questions designed to assess participants' financial knowledge. The pre-post assessment can be found in Appendix A.
Key Topics:
Personal budgeting
Savings and investment strategies
Understanding loans and interest rates
Cost-benefit analysis of sustainable practices
Format: Multiple-choice questionnaire.
Administration: Paper-based or electronic, depending on available resources.
Scoring Template: Answer key provided for quick scoring
4.2 Post-Module Evaluation and Feedback
This form supports a structured approach to evaluate each module's effectiveness and identify areas for improvement. It will be delivered at the end of a training course or module.
Sections:
Content relevance and clarity
Trainer effectiveness
Training materials and resources
Engagement and participation
Suggestions for improvement
Format: Combination of Likert-scale questions and open-ended responses.
Administration: Distributed at the end of the training session.
Data Entry Template: Standardized form for easy data entry and analysis.
All post-module evaluation forms can be found in this folder.

4.3 Post-Module Quiz
The post-module quiz is customized for each module, you can find digital versions that grade themselves automatically, as well as printable versions in the folder for each module here, and a sample quiz for Module 2 is included in Appendix B. 
 
4.3 Data Collection Templates

The implementing partner should create and maintain the following templates to aggregate data from the modules and training sessions.
Participant Register: Template to record participant details and attendance.
Score Sheet: Spreadsheet to record pre/post-assessment scores and quiz scores.
Trainer/Module Feedback Summary Sheet: Template to compile and analyze feedback from participants on the trainer and module quality..
5. Implementation Plan
The following describes an overview of the M&E implementation plan and process for the implementing partner. 
5.1 Types of Data
Quantitative Analysis: Score pre/post-tests to measure knowledge gains. If pre-post test is taken using Google Forms, auto-scoring capabilities is possible.
Aggregate post-module quiz scores to identify the percentage of students meeting qualifying measurements. 
Disaggregation: Analyze data by gender, age, and other relevant groups to assess equity and inclusion.
Qualitative Analysis: Leverage LLMs to thematically analyze open-ended feedback from evaluation reports and quizzes. 
Content Analysis: Review open-ended feedback for common themes and suggestions.
Gather Case Studies: The implementing partner can document success stories and best practices.
5.2 Data Analysis Procedures
Pre/Post-Assessment Comparison:
Calculate the percentage increase in scores for each participant.
Analyze the average score improvement across all participants.
Identify topics with the most significant knowledge gains or gaps.
Feedback Analysis:
Quantify responses from feedback forms (e.g., average satisfaction ratings).
Identify common themes in qualitative feedback.
Competency Achievement:
Determine the percentage of participants meeting the competency criteria.
Analyze competency achievement by demographic variables (e.g., gender, age).
5.3 Reporting
M&E Reports:
Implementing partners is to discuss with the ITC to identify the reporting schedule and will prepare regular reports summarizing findings.
It’s recommended to include data visualizations (e.g., graphs, charts) to illustrate results.
Highlight success stories and areas for improvement.
Impact Assessment:
Report on the number of participants demonstrating increased knowledge (aligns with Indicator 3.3.3).
Document the number of firms benefiting from the training (aligns with Indicator 3.3.1).
6. Roles and Responsibilities
Implementing Partner / M&E Coordinator:
Oversee the implementation of the M&E framework.
Ensure data quality and integrity.
Prepare and submit M&E reports.
Trainers/Facilitators:
Administer pre/post-assessments and feedback forms.
Optionally record and report observations during training sessions.
Provide feedback to the M&E Coordinator.
7. Expected Outcomes and Targets
Based on the BEIT Logframe Indicators:
Indicator 3.3.1:
Target: 200 firms benefiting from green Business Development Services(BDS).
Means of Verification: Documentary evidence from Business Development Services and TVET institutions; M&E system records (outside the scope of this training M&E system)
Indicator 3.3.2:
Target: 500 people benefiting from TVET/skills development interventions.
Means of Verification: M&E system records; attendance registers.
Indicator 3.3.3:
Target: 500 people demonstrating increased knowledge in financial literacy.
Means of Verification: Pre- and post-training tests; M&E system records.
Indicator 3.3.4:
Target: 5 key support organizations showing improved performance.
Means of Verification: M&E system records; performance assessments. (Outside the scope of this training M&E system)
8. Conclusion
The M&E framework provides a structured approach to assess the effectiveness of the BEIT Modular Training Project for Sustainable Housing and Reconstruction. By systematically collecting and analyzing data, the project can demonstrate its impact, make informed decisions for future training improvements, and contribute to the overall goals of promoting decent work and affordable housing in Iraq.

Additional Recommendations
Adaptation for Other Modules: While this framework has pre-post assessments for the financial literacy module, similar tools and methodologies can be adapted for the rest of the training modules within the program. 
Collaborative M&E Improvement: Regularly review and update the M&E framework to reflect lessons learned and changes in project scope alongside the implementing partner to integrate with their tools and systems.

9. Appendices
Appendix A: Financial Literacy Pre/Post-Test

**Gathering insights**

I’m thoroughly reading the M&E report, identifying inconsistencies and suggesting improvements while ensuring all parts are policy-compliant. No disallowed content found.

**Evaluating capacity building**

I'm harnessing straightforward, paper-based evaluative tools to foster financial literacy among young entrepreneurs, ensuring continuous curriculum refinement and program impact assessment.

**Evaluating and aligning**

I’m gathering info on how the M&E framework rates training and integrates ADDIE for continuous process improvement, while aligning with specific BEIT output indicators.

**Breaking down the learning journey**

I’m examining the analysis phase to pinpoint learning goals. The design phase focuses on crafting objectives, while the development phase involves refining the curriculum based on feedback. The evaluation phase assesses each module's impact, using Pre- and Post-Training Assessments to gauge learning outcomes.

**Crafting the evaluation framework**

I’m thinking through the M&E approach, aligning needs with the ADDIE framework, and using pre-post test assessments, a post-module evaluation form, and a post-module quiz for the Financial Literacy module to streamline data acquisition and enhance the training program.

**Ensuring evaluation clarity**

I'm pulling together a structured post-module evaluation form to assess content, trainer effectiveness, and engagement. Adjustments might be made after piloting to enhance clarity.

**Crafting data templates**

I’m refining data collection by creating participant registers, score sheets, and feedback summaries. This approach ensures systematic tracking of attendance, assessment scores, and trainer/module feedback.

**Harnessing analysis tools**

OK, let me see. By using Google Forms for pre-post tests and aggregating post-module quiz scores, I’m piecing together data on gender and age groups. Qualitatively, I’m using LLMs to identify key themes and suggestions in feedback.

**Evaluating progress**

Calculating score increases, analyzing feedback, and assessing demographic gaps to gauge knowledge shifts.

**Clarifying roles**

I’m detailing the responsibilities of the M&E Coordinator and Trainers/Facilitators, including data integrity, report preparation, and observation management.

**Setting and assessing targets**

I’ve mapped out specific targets: 200 firms and 500 individuals benefiting from BDS, 500 individuals gain financial literacy, and 5 organizations show improved performance with clear verification methods.

**Identifying gaps**

I'm noting that the appendices are incomplete, and there are inconsistencies in numbering and references to nonexistent sections or documents.

**Evaluating the framework**

Noting the potential for expanding the financial literacy framework to other training modules, the use of LLMs in data analysis, and the need for clearer delineation of roles between the implementing partner and ITC.

### Refining grammatical structure

I’m noting that the sentence under "M&E Reports" has grammatical errors and inconsistencies in the use of "implementing partner" vs "partners". There is also a need for more detailed explanations in the ADDIE model phases of the document.

**Evaluating ADDIE model**

I’m piecing together the alignment of the ADDIE model with M&E components. Clarity issues and inaccuracies in mapping phases are noticeable, with phases like "Develop" and "Evaluate" requiring adjustments for better precision.

**Noticing inconsistencies**

I encountered a typo, assessed naming inconsistencies in the project, questioned the document's future date, and identified areas for improving clarity, detail, and alignment with project objectives.

**Critique of the Monitoring and Evaluation Framework for the BEIT Project**

The Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework for the Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) Project presents a comprehensive approach to assessing the effectiveness of training modules, particularly focusing on financial literacy. While the framework covers essential components, there are several incongruities and areas for improvement to enhance its clarity, coherence, and applicability.

---

### **1. Structural and Numbering Inconsistencies**

- **Numbering Errors in Section 4:**
  - There are two subsections labeled **4.3**:
    - **4.3 Post-Module Quiz**
    - **4.3 Data Collection Templates**
  - **Recommendation:** Renumber the subsections sequentially to maintain consistency (e.g., 4.3 and 4.4).

- **Incomplete Sections and References:**
  - References to "this folder," "Appendix A," and "Appendix B" lack accompanying content or accessible links.
  - **Recommendation:** Include the actual content of the appendices or provide clear instructions on how to access these materials. Ensure all referenced materials are attached or appropriately linked within the document.

---

### **2. Content Gaps and Incomplete Information**

- **Incomplete Sentences and Ideas:**
  - In **Section 1.2**, under **Feedback Forms**, the bullet point ends abruptly with "names," suggesting missing information.
  - **Recommendation:** Complete the sentence to clarify what specific information is to be gathered (e.g., "Feedback Forms: Participant feedback forms to gather qualitative data on training effectiveness, including participant names and contact information for follow-up.").

- **Missing Implementation Phase in ADDIE Model:**
  - The **Implement** phase is not explicitly detailed in **Section 3**, disrupting the logical flow of the ADDIE model.
  - **Recommendation:** Include a dedicated subsection for the **Implement** phase, outlining activities such as conducting the training sessions, administering assessments, and collecting immediate feedback.

---

### **3. Misalignment with the ADDIE Model**

- **Incorrect Sequencing and Mapping:**
  - Activities and tools listed under certain phases do not align accurately with the standard ADDIE model. For example, feedback tools are placed under **Develop** rather than **Implement** or **Evaluate**.
  - **Recommendation:** Reorganize **Section 3** to correctly map activities and tools to the appropriate ADDIE phases:
    - **Analyze:** Needs assessments and stakeholder consultations.
    - **Design:** Development of learning objectives and assessment strategies.
    - **Develop:** Creation of training materials and M&E tools.
    - **Implement:** Execution of training sessions and administration of assessments.
    - **Evaluate:** Analysis of collected data, reporting, and feedback for continuous improvement.

---

### **4. Clarity and Consistency in Language**

- **Inconsistent Terminology:**
  - The document alternates between "implementing partner" and "implementing partners," causing confusion.
  - **Recommendation:** Choose a consistent term throughout the document and define it in the roles and responsibilities section.

- **Grammatical Errors:**
  - In **Section 5.3**, the sentence "Implementing partners is to discuss with the ITC..." contains a subject-verb agreement error.
  - **Recommendation:** Correct the sentence to "The implementing partner is to discuss with the ITC..."

---

### **5. Overemphasis on Financial Literacy Module**

- **Limited Scope of M&E Tools:**
  - The framework heavily focuses on the financial literacy module, with less emphasis on other training modules.
  - **Recommendation:** Expand the M&E tools and strategies to encompass all modules within the BEIT training program, ensuring a comprehensive evaluation approach.

- **Adaptation for Other Modules:**
  - The **Additional Recommendations** section suggests adapting tools for other modules but lacks specific guidance.
  - **Recommendation:** Provide examples or templates of how pre/post-assessments and feedback forms can be tailored for other modules.

---

### **6. Practicality of Using LLMs for Data Analysis**

- **Feasibility Concerns:**
  - In **Section 5.1**, the suggestion to "leverage LLMs to thematically analyze open-ended feedback" may not be practical due to resource constraints or data privacy issues.
  - **Recommendation:** Consider alternative qualitative analysis methods, such as manual coding or using qualitative data analysis software that complies with data protection regulations.

---

### **7. Data Privacy and Ethical Considerations**

- **Participant Data Handling:**
  - The framework does not address how participant data will be protected, especially when using electronic tools or potentially sharing data with third parties (e.g., when using LLMs).
  - **Recommendation:** Include a section on data privacy, outlining measures for data security, informed consent, and compliance with relevant data protection laws.

---

### **8. Roles and Responsibilities Enhancement**

- **Detailed Role Definitions:**
  - The roles of the **Implementing Partner**, **M&E Coordinator**, and **Trainers/Facilitators** are briefly mentioned but lack detailed responsibilities.
  - **Recommendation:** Elaborate on each role, specifying tasks, accountability mechanisms, and collaboration processes to ensure clarity and effective implementation.

---

### **9. Alignment with BEIT Logframe Indicators**

- **Scope Clarification:**
  - Some indicators are marked as "outside the scope of this training M&E system," which may cause confusion about the framework's focus.
  - **Recommendation:** Clearly delineate which indicators are addressed by this M&E framework and adjust the Expected Outcomes and Targets section to reflect only those within scope.

---

### **10. Enhancement of Reporting Procedures**

- **Reporting Schedule and Content:**
  - The framework mentions that the implementing partner will discuss the reporting schedule with the ITC but lacks specifics.
  - **Recommendation:** Propose a tentative reporting timeline (e.g., monthly, quarterly) and outline the expected content of the M&E reports to facilitate planning and accountability.

---

### **11. Inclusion of Appendices and Supplementary Materials**

- **Missing Appendices:**
  - The document references **Appendix A** and **Appendix B**, but these are not included.
  - **Recommendation:** Attach the appendices or indicate when and how they will be made available. Ensure all supplementary materials are complete and accessible to relevant stakeholders.

---

### **12. Consistency in Project Naming and Scope**

- **Project Focus Variations:**
  - The conclusion references the "BEIT Modular Training Project for Sustainable Housing and Reconstruction," which may differ from earlier descriptions.
  - **Recommendation:** Use consistent project titles and descriptions throughout the document to avoid confusion about the project's objectives and scope.

---

### **13. Formatting and Presentation Improvements**

- **Use of Visual Aids:**
  - The document is text-heavy and could benefit from visual elements to enhance understanding.
  - **Recommendation:** Incorporate tables, flowcharts, or diagrams to illustrate the M&E process, the ADDIE model integration, and roles and responsibilities.

- **Clear Section Headings:**
  - Ensure all section headings are numbered correctly and reflect the content accurately for better navigation.

---

### **14. Future-proofing and Sustainability**

- **Continuous Improvement Mechanisms:**
  - While the framework mentions regular reviews, it lacks a structured process for how lessons learned will be integrated.
  - **Recommendation:** Establish a formal mechanism for periodic review and adaptation of the M&E framework, involving key stakeholders in the process.

---

### **15. Cultural and Contextual Sensitivity**

- **Adaptation to Local Context:**
  - The framework should address how tools and methodologies will be tailored to fit the cultural and contextual realities of Iraq, especially considering potential literacy levels and access to technology.
  - **Recommendation:** Include strategies for culturally appropriate data collection and consider alternative methods where technological solutions are impractical.

---

**Conclusion**

The M&E Framework for the BEIT Project lays a solid foundation for evaluating the effectiveness of its training programs. By addressing the identified incongruities and implementing the recommended improvements, the framework can become more robust, user-friendly, and aligned with the project's goals. Enhancing clarity, ensuring consistency, and expanding the scope of evaluation tools will contribute significantly to the project's success in promoting decent work and affordable housing in Iraq.

Introduction** #### **1.1 Background** The Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) project aims to stimulate decent work opportunities for young women and men while addressing the urgent need for affordable housing in Iraq. Under Output 3.3, the project focuses on strengthening the capacities of local businesses, particularly young entrepreneurs, by integrating green and innovative practices into their operations. This includes providing financial literacy training to enhance their knowledge and skills. #### **1.2 Purpose of the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework** The purpose of this M&E framework is to align continual curriculum improvements, as described in the Material Validation report, with the required M&E results for the BEIT project. Based on our experience working in Mosul, we have identified the need to leverage simple, paper-based tools to gather the required data. The framework includes: - **Assessment Tools:** Pre- and post-assessment quizzes to measure knowledge acquisition for the Financial Literacy Module. - **Feedback Forms:** Participant feedback forms to gather qualitative data on training quality, trainer effectiveness, training materials and resources, and overall satisfaction. - **Competency Criteria:** Specific criteria for measuring competency acquisition among participants. - **Data Collection and Analysis Methodologies:** Procedures for collecting, analyzing, and reporting data to inform future training improvements and assess the program's impact. --- ### **2. M&E Framework Overview** #### **2.1 Objectives** - **Assess Learning Outcomes:** Measure the increase in participants' knowledge and skills as a result of the training. - **Evaluate Training Effectiveness:** Gather feedback on training delivery, content relevance, and participant satisfaction. - **Inform Program Improvements:** Use data to refine training materials and methodologies. - **Report on Impact:** Provide evidence of the training program's impact on professionals in the construction and housing sector. #### **2.2 Alignment with BEIT Logframe Indicators** The M&E framework aligns with the following BEIT Output 3.3 indicators: - **Indicator 3.3.1:** Number of firms benefiting from green Business Development Services (BDS). - **Indicator 3.3.2:** Number of people who have benefited from institution or workplace-based TVET/skills development interventions. - **Indicator 3.3.3:** Number of people benefiting from financial literacy training who can demonstrate increased knowledge. - **Indicator 3.3.4:** Number of key support organizations having improved operational or managerial performance as a result of ITC support. --- ### **3. Integration of the ADDIE Model into the M&E Framework** The ADDIE model consists of five phases: Analyze, Design, Develop, Implement, and Evaluate. Each phase includes specific activities and corresponding monitoring and evaluation components. #### **Analyze** - **Activities:** - Identify learning needs and objectives. - Conduct needs assessment surveys and focus groups to collect data on learners' existing knowledge and skills. - **M&E Components:** - Analysis of needs assessment data (details can be found in the Stakeholder Engagement Recommendations and Material Validation report). #### **Design** - **Activities:** - Develop learning objectives and outcomes based on analysis. - Design assessment strategies and feedback mechanisms. - **M&E Components:** - Creation of assessment tools and feedback forms aligned with learning objectives. #### **Develop** - **Activities:** - Update training content based on insights and design outputs. - Prepare training materials and resources. - **M&E Components:** - Validation of training materials. - Pilot testing of assessment tools. #### **Implement** - **Activities:** - Execute training sessions and administer assessments. - Collect real-time feedback during training sessions. - **M&E Components:** - **Post-Module Feedback Forms:** Gather insights from participants to inform curriculum improvements. - **Training Feedback Forms:** Collect immediate feedback on training effectiveness. - **Observation Reports:** Trainers assess engagement and participation levels, reporting insights and concerns to the implementing partner. #### **Evaluate** - **Activities:** - Analyze collected data, report findings, and provide feedback for continuous improvement. - Return to the Analyze phase and continue the ADDIE cycle. - **M&E Components:** - **Pre- and Post-Training Assessments:** Measure learning outcomes for financial literacy (found in Appendix A). - **Post-Module Quiz:** Assess understanding and qualify learners for module completion (70% or more required). - **Post-Module Assessments:** Evaluate each module's impact; web-fillable forms and printable PDFs are available in the resource folder. --- ### **4. Tools and Instruments of the M&E Framework** Our goal in the M&E approach is to align M&E needs with the ADDIE continuous improvement framework for the curriculum. This streamlines the data acquisition process and leverages needed information for developing a stronger training program. #### **4.1 Financial Literacy Pre/Post-Test Questionnaire** A standardized test to be delivered before and after the Financial Literacy Module, comprising multiple-choice and short-answer questions designed to assess participants' financial knowledge. - **Key Topics:** - Personal budgeting - Savings and investment strategies - Understanding loans and interest rates - Cost-benefit analysis of sustainable practices - **Format:** Multiple-choice and short-answer questions. - **Administration:** Paper-based or electronic, depending on available resources. - **Scoring Template:** Answer key provided for quick scoring. #### **4.2 Post-Module Evaluation and Feedback** This form supports a structured approach to evaluate each module's effectiveness and identify areas for improvement. It will be delivered at the end of a training course or module. - **Sections:** - Content relevance and clarity - Trainer effectiveness - Training materials and resources - Engagement and participation - Suggestions for improvement - **Format:** Combination of Likert-scale questions and open-ended responses. - **Administration:** Distributed at the end of the training session. - **Data Entry Template:** Standardized form for easy data entry and analysis. - **Note:** All post-module evaluation forms can be found in the resource folder. #### **4.3 Post-Module Quiz** The post-module quiz is customized for each module. - **Format:** Multiple-choice or short-answer questions. - **Administration:** Available in digital versions that grade themselves automatically, as well as printable versions. - **Resources:** Digital and printable versions are available in the folder for each module. A sample quiz for Module 2 is included in Appendix B. #### **4.4 Data Collection Templates** The implementing partner should create and maintain the following templates to aggregate data from the modules and training sessions. - **Participant Register:** Template to record participant details and attendance. - **Score Sheet:** Spreadsheet to record pre/post-assessment scores and quiz scores. - **Trainer/Module Feedback Summary Sheet:** Template to compile and analyze feedback from participants on trainer and module quality. --- ### **5. Implementation Plan** #### **5.1 Types of Data** - **Quantitative Data:** - Score pre/post-tests to measure knowledge gains. - Aggregate post-module quiz scores to identify the percentage of students meeting qualifying measurements. - **Disaggregation:** Analyze data by gender, age, and other relevant groups to assess equity and inclusion. - **Qualitative Data:** - Review open-ended feedback for common themes and suggestions. - Gather case studies documenting success stories and best practices. #### **5.2 Data Analysis Procedures** - **Pre/Post-Assessment Comparison:** - Calculate the percentage increase in scores for each participant. - Analyze the average score improvement across all participants. - Identify topics with the most significant knowledge gains or gaps. - **Feedback Analysis:** - Quantify responses from feedback forms (e.g., average satisfaction ratings). - Identify common themes in qualitative feedback. - **Competency Achievement:** - Determine the percentage of participants meeting the competency criteria. - Analyze competency achievement by demographic variables (e.g., gender, age). #### **5.3 Reporting** - **M&E Reports:** - The implementing partner will discuss the reporting schedule with the ITC and prepare regular reports summarizing findings. - Include data visualizations (e.g., graphs, charts) to illustrate results. - Highlight success stories and areas for improvement. - **Impact Assessment:** - Report on the number of participants demonstrating increased knowledge (aligns with Indicator 3.3.3). - Document the number of firms benefiting from the training (aligns with Indicator 3.3.1). --- ### **6. Roles and Responsibilities** #### **Implementing Partner / M&E Coordinator** - **Responsibilities:** - Oversee the implementation of the M&E framework. - Ensure data quality and integrity. - Prepare and submit M&E reports according to the agreed schedule. - Coordinate with trainers and stakeholders to facilitate data collection. - Maintain confidentiality and ethical standards in data handling. #### **Trainers/Facilitators** - **Responsibilities:** - Administer pre/post-assessments and feedback forms. - Record and report observations during training sessions. - Provide feedback to the M&E Coordinator. - Assist in data collection and ensure timely submission of required documents. --- ### **7. Expected Outcomes and Targets** Based on the BEIT Logframe Indicators: - **Indicator 3.3.1:** - **Target:** 200 firms benefiting from green Business Development Services (BDS). - **Means of Verification:** Documentary evidence from BDS and TVET institutions; M&E system records. - **Indicator 3.3.2:** - **Target:** 500 people benefiting from TVET/skills development interventions. - **Means of Verification:** M&E system records; attendance registers. - **Indicator 3.3.3:** - **Target:** 500 people demonstrating increased knowledge in financial literacy. - **Means of Verification:** Pre- and post-training tests; M&E system records. - **Indicator 3.3.4:** - **Target:** 5 key support organizations showing improved performance. - **Means of Verification:** M&E system records; performance assessments. **Note:** Indicators 3.3.1 and 3.3.4 involve aspects outside the scope of this training M&E framework but are included here for alignment purposes. --- ### **8. Data Privacy and Ethical Considerations** #### **Data Protection** - Ensure all participant data is collected, stored, and processed in compliance with applicable data protection laws and regulations. - Implement secure data storage solutions with restricted access. #### **Informed Consent** - Obtain informed consent from all participants before data collection. - Clearly explain the purpose of data collection and how the data will be used. #### **Confidentiality** - Maintain the confidentiality of participant responses. - Anonymize data where possible, especially in reports and publications. #### **Ethical Standards** - Adhere to ethical guidelines in all M&E activities. - Respect cultural sensitivities and participant rights. --- ### **9. Conclusion** The M&E framework provides a structured approach to assess the effectiveness of the BEIT project. By systematically collecting and analyzing data, the project can demonstrate its impact, make informed decisions for future training improvements, and contribute to the overall goals of promoting decent work and affordable housing in Iraq. --- ### **10. Additional Recommendations** #### **Adaptation for Other Modules** - While this framework has pre-post assessments for the financial literacy module, similar tools and methodologies can be adapted for the rest of the training modules within the program. - Develop module-specific assessment tools and feedback forms to evaluate the entire curriculum comprehensively. #### **Collaborative M&E Improvement** - Regularly review and update the M&E framework to reflect lessons learned and changes in project scope. - Collaborate with the implementing partner to integrate with their tools and systems effectively. #### **Reporting Schedule** - Establish a clear reporting schedule (e.g., monthly, quarterly) in consultation with the ITC to ensure timely communication of M&E findings. --- ### **11.
